thread.title: Tonnes of watermelons smashed, eaten in annual Queensland festival
thread.title_full: Tonnes of watermelons smashed, eaten in annual Queensland festival

author: Elly Bradfield
title: Tonnes of watermelons smashed, eaten in annual Queensland festival
text:
By Elly Bradfield Posted  22:54 Map: Chinchilla 4413 
More than 20 tonnes of watermelon have been smashed all in the name of fun and games as part of the annual Chinchilla Melon Festival on Queensland's Western Downs. 
Thousands of people including interstate and international tourists braved extreme heat on Saturday to take part in the event, including a beach party, melon rodeo, melon games and street parade. 
Event president Doug McNally said the last festival brought $3.5 million into the community. 
"I think it's a great injection for the town," he said. 
"A few of the moteliers have been doing it a bit tough since the downturn in the coal seam gas game, this is just a real shot in the arm for everybody." 
Mr McNally said in addition to the 20 tonnes of watermelons used during the events, about six tonnes of best quality melons would be eaten. External Link: Kerrin Binnie on Twitter: Melon skiiing in Chinchilla 'You say you grow watermelons and everyone smiles' 
Watermelon grower Terry O'Leary said the town had sweltered though 18 days above 40 degrees Celsius this year, halving yield. 
"In the last seven years we've gone from lowest rainfall on record, highest rainfall on record to hail storms wiping out our entire crop days before picking and this year 18 days about 40 degrees â€” so every year is a challenge," he said. 
"We've got floods, hail storms, drought but the community all comes together and the growers seem to be able to punch out the product year after year and this is what it does for the town." 
He said despite the challenges, he remained passionate about the industry. 
"I had a few years where I sat behind an office desk and as good as that was it's not something that I was really passionate about," he said. Photo: Thousands of people lined the streets as part of the parade on Saturday. (ABC News: Elly Bradfield) 
"When you go up to anybody and they ask, 'what is it you do for a living?' and you say you grow watermelons, everyone smiles. 
"If people say, 'what do you do for a living?' and it's grow Brussel sprouts people don't get as excited. 
"I love the flavour, they're a great product to grow, they work perfect here with our natural environment. 
"Everybody seems to associate watermelons with a happy fun time."
